article.headline: St. Bonaventure 78, Robert Morris 76
article.story: OLEAN, N.Y. (AP) -- Marques Green scored 28 points to lead St. Bonaventure to a 78-76 comeback win over Robert Morris on Friday in the Bonnies' first game after last season's troubled finish. Green scored 17 points in the second half, rallying the Bonnies to overcome a 61-50 deficit over the final eight minutes. Ahmad Smith made the key defensive play for St. Bonaventure, blocking Colonials' guard Maurice Carter's potential game-tying basket, an eight-footer as time ran out. Chaz McCrommon scored 24 points, and Carter added 16 and had seven assists in Robert Morris' season-opener. It was an emotional finish for a St. Bonaventure program seeking a fresh start after last season ended abruptly because of a player eligibility scandal. The Bonnies players forfeited their final two games when the Atlantic 10 Conference barred the team from postseason play after forward Jamil Terrell was ruled ineligible for failing to meet junior college transfer guidelines. Fittingly, it was Green, the team's captain and only senior, that proved to be the difference in the Bonnies' first game since a 78-77 loss at Temple on March 1. Green scored 11 points in the final three minutes, including the go-ahead basket. It happened when he capped a strong drive from the top of the key with a crossover dribble and a layup to give the Bonnies a 73-72 lead with 1:19 remaining. On the Colonials ensuing possession, Green then stripped the ball from Chris Gooden and, at the other end, pulled up to hit his seventh 3-point basket of the game. The game was also St. Bonaventure's first at the Reilly Center since a 94-89 overtime win against George Washington on Feb. 26. A less-than-capacity crowd of about 5,000 was enthusiastic to begin the night, cheering "Solomon" as new coach Anthony Solomon took the floor. But there was little to cheer about when the Bonnies came out flat, hitting only 12 of its first 35 field goal attempts to trail 39-35 at the half. The crowd spent most of the final 10 minutes on its feet. Much has changed since St. Bonaventure last played. School president Robert Wickenheiser and athletic director Gothard Lane resigned and coach Jan van Breda Kolff was dismissed last spring because of the scandal. In August, the school's trustees chairman William Swan committed suicide in part because of a belief he had let down his alma mater. His wife Ann Swan drove in from Buffalo to attend the game, and was welcomed with several emotional hugs from friends and school officials, including interim St. Bonaventure president the Rev. Dominic Monti. After the game, Monti presented coach Solomon with a brick, symbolizing the new foundation he's building.
